title: SB 66
content:
The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature recognizes the importance of middle skill credentials for economic competitiveness and upward mobility in California. These credentials are defined as certifications, associate's degrees, or third-party credentials that are essential for various careers in prioritized industry sectors. The Strong Workforce Task Force identified 25 policy recommendations to close the gap on middle skill credentials, building upon existing programs and federal laws. California agencies have adopted common program strategies under the federal Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act. The Strong Workforce Task Force identified 25 policy recommendations to close the gap on middle skill credentials, building upon existing programs and federal laws. Partnering in sector strategies, building career pathways, utilizing “earn and learn,” organizing regionally, providing supportive services, creating cross-system data capacity, integrating service delivery, and braiding resources are key strategies outlined for effective workforce development. Section 30 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to require applicants to provide their federal employer identification number or social security number at the time of license issuance. Individual taxpayer identification number or social security number will be required for individual applicants by January 1, 2016. Licensees failing to provide federal employer identification number, individual taxpayer identification number, or social security number will be reported to the Franchise Tax Board. Failure to provide this information may result in penalties. Additionally, licensing boards will not process applications for initial licenses without the required identification numbers. The licensing board must provide specific information about licensees to the Franchise Tax Board or the Employment Development Department upon request. This includes the licensee's name, address, federal employer identification number, type of license, effective and expiration dates, and license status. A licensee is defined as a person or entity authorized to engage in a regulated business or profession. The licensing board must provide necessary information to the Franchise Tax Board or Employment Development Department in a machine-readable format as required. The licensing board must provide confidential identification numbers to specific entities, and individuals with access to this information must maintain its confidentiality. The Legislature intends to use federal identification numbers for establishing identification in state tax laws, compliance with the Family Code, and measuring employment outcomes of students in career technical education programs at California Community Colleges. The board may release an individual taxpayer identification number or social security number to an examination or licensing entity for verification purposes if a reciprocity agreement exists between California and the requesting state. (l) For enforcement of Section 17520 of the Family Code, boards, the State Bar, and the Bureau of Real Estate must require licensees to provide taxpayer identification numbers or social security numbers. Licensee refers to entities issued licenses by various agencies.
(m) The department will provide licensee information to the Office of the Chancellor of the California Community Colleges upon request, including names. The curr_chunk provides details required for licensing, including name, identification numbers, date of birth, type of license, and expiration dates. The information is shared with the Chancellor's office for measuring employment outcomes of students in career technical education programs, with compliance to privacy laws. The department may limit licensure information availability to protect security and privacy rights. Information shared must be necessary, not personally identifiable, and not shared without consent. The Education Code requires protection of information with security measures, immediate destruction when no longer needed, and allows sharing with third parties under certain conditions. The Education Code mandates the implementation of performance accountability measures for the economic and workforce development program, aligning with federal standards. The chancellor must submit an annual report to the Governor and Legislature detailing program expenditures and outcomes for employers and students. Data summarizing outcome accountability performance measures required by this section.
